revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{Infobox deity | type = Greek | name = Demeter | other_names = Sito, Thesmophoros | god_of = Goddess of agriculture, harvest, fertility and sacred law. | member_of = | image = Demeter Altemps Inv8546.jpg | caption = A marble statue of Demeter, [[National Roman Museum]] | abode = [[Mount Olympus]] | symbol = [[Cornucopia]], [[wheat]], [[torch]], [[bread]] | consort = [[Iasion]], [[Zeus]], [[Oceanus]], [[Karmanor]], [[Poseidon]] and [[Triptolemus]] | parents = [[Cronus]] and [[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]] | siblings = [[Hestia]], [[Hera]], [[Hades]], [[Poseidon]], [[Zeus]], [[Chiron]] | children = [[Persephone]], [[Despoina]], [[Arion (mythology)|Arion]], [[Plutus]], [[Philomelus]], [[Eubuleus]], [[Chrysothemis]], and [[Amphitheus I]] | mount = | festivals = [[Thesmophoria]] | Roman_equivalent = [[Ceres (mythology)|Ceres]] }} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Special characters}} {{Ancient Greek religion}}
In [[ancient Greek religion]] and [[Greek mythology|mythology]], '''Demeter''' ({{IPAc-en|d|ɪ|ˈ|m|iː|t|ər|}}; [[Attic Greek|Attic]]: {{lang|grc|Δημήτηρ}} ''Dēmḗtēr'', {{IPA-el|dɛːmɛ́ːtɛːr|pron}}; [[Doric Greek|Doric]]: {{lang|grc|Δαμάτηρ}} ''Dāmā́tēr'') is the goddess of the grain, agriculture, harvest, growth, and nourishment, who presided over [[grain]]s and the [[fertility (soil)|fertility]] of the earth. Her cult titles include Sito ({{lang|grc|Σιτώ}}), "she of the Grain",<ref>{{LSJ|*sitw/|Σιτώ}}. [[Cf.]] {{LSJ|si{{=}}tos|σῖτος|ref}}.</ref> as the giver of food or grain,<ref>[[Eustathius of Thessalonica]], scholia on [[Homer]], 265.</ref> and [[Thesmophoria|Thesmophoros]] ({{lang|grc|θεσμός}}, ''thesmos'': divine order, unwritten law; {{lang|grc|φόρος}}, ''phoros'': bringer, bearer), "Law-Bringer", as a mark of the civilized existence of agricultural society.<ref name=Finley78>[[Themis]] was an ancient Greek goddess, embodiment of divine order, law. She was the organizer of the communal affairs and she evoked the social order: Finley, ''The World of Odysseus'', rev. ed. Viking Press. (1978:78 note 82)</ref>
Though Demeter is often described simply as the goddess of the harvest, she presided also over the [[religious law|sacred law]], and the cycle of life and death. She and her daughter [[Persephone]] were the central figures of the [[Eleusinian Mysteries]] that predated the [[Olympian pantheon]]. In the [[Linear B]] [[Mycenean Greek]] tablets of c. 1400–1200 BC found at [[Pylos]], the "two queens and the king" may be related with Demeter, [[Persephone]] and [[Poseidon]].<ref>[[John Chadwick]], ''The Mycenean World''. Cambridge University Press, 1976.</ref><ref name=Mylonas159>"Wa-na-ssoi, wa-na-ka-te, (to the two queens and the king). Wanax is best suited to Poseidon, the special divinity of Pylos. The identity of the two divinities addressed as wanassoi, is uncertain ": George Mylonas (1966) Mycenae and the Mycenean age" p.159 :Princeton University Press</ref> Her [[Interpretatio graeca|Roman equivalent]] is [[Ceres (mythology)|Ceres]].<ref name="Lar">''Larousse Desk Reference Encyclopedia'', [[The Book People]], Haydock, 1995, p. 215.</ref>
== Etymology == It is possible that Demeter appears in [[Linear A]] as ''da-ma-te'' on three documents ([[Arkalochori|AR]] Zf 1 and 2, and [[Kythera|KY]] Za 2), all three apparently dedicated in religious situations and all three bearing just the name (''i-da-ma-te'' on AR Zf 1 and 2).<ref>Y. Duhoux, "LA > B da-ma-te = Déméter? Sur la langue du linéaire A," Minos 29/30 (1994-1995): 289–294.</ref> It is unlikely that Demeter appears as ''da-ma-te'' in a [[Linear B]] ([[Mycenean Greek]]) inscription ([[Pylos|PY]] En 609); the word {{lang|gmy|𐀅𐀔𐀳}}, ''da-ma-te'', probably refers to "households".<ref>Y. Duhoux and A. Morpurgo-Davies, Companion to Linear B, vol. 2 (2011), p. 26. But see Ventris/Chadwick,''Documents in Mycenean Greek'' p.242: B.Dietriech (2004):''The origins of the Greek religion'' Bristol Phoenix Press. p.172</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=da-ma-te|url=http://minoan.deaditerranean.com/resources/linear-b-sign-groups/da/da-ma-te/|website=Deaditerranean. Minoan Linear A & Mycenaean Linear B}} {{cite web|website=DĀMOS: Database of Mycenaean at Oslo|url=https://www2.hf.uio.no/damos/Index/item/chosen_item_id/4560|publisher=[[University of Oslo]]|title=PY 609 En (1)}}</ref> On the other hand, {{lang|gmy|𐀯𐀵𐀡𐀴𐀛𐀊}}, ''si-to-po-ti-ni-ja'', "[[Potnia]] of the Grain", is regarded as referring to her [[Bronze Age]] predecessor or to one of her [[epithet]]s.<ref>Inscription [[Mycenae|MY]] Oi 701. {{cite web|title=si-to-po-ti-ni-ja|url=http://minoan.deaditerranean.com/resources/linear-b-sign-groups/si/si-to-po-ti-ni-ja/|website=Deaditerranean. Minoan Linear A & Mycenaean Linear B}} {{cite web|publisher=Palaeolexicon. Word study tool of Ancient languages |url=http://www.palaeolexicon.com/ShowWord.aspx?Id=16929|title=The Linear B word si-to}} {{cite web|website=DĀMOS: Database of Mycenaean at Oslo|url=https://www2.hf.uio.no/damos/Index/item/chosen_item_id/5609|publisher=[[University of Oslo]]|title=MY 701 Oi (63)}} Cf. {{lang|grc|σῖτος, Σιτώ}}.</ref>
Demeter's character as [[mother-goddess]] is identified in the second element of her name ''meter'' ({{lang|grc|μήτηρ}}) derived from [[Proto-Indo-European language|Proto-Indo-European]] ''*méh₂tēr'' (mother).<ref>[http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=mother Online Etymology Dictionary "mother"]</ref> In antiquity, different explanations were already proffered for the first element of her name. It is possible that ''Da'' ({{lang|grc|Δᾶ}}),<ref>{{LSJ|da{{=}}2|Δᾶ|shortref}}.</ref> a word which corresponds to ''Ge'' ({{lang|grc|Γῆ}}) in Attic, is the Doric form of ''De'' ({{lang|grc|Δῆ}}), "earth", the old name of the [[chthonic]] earth-goddess, and that Demeter is "Mother-Earth".<ref>[http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=Demeter Online Etymology Dictionary "Demeter"]</ref> This root also appears in the [[Linear B]] inscription ''E-ne-si-da-o-ne'', "earth-shaker", as an aspect of the god [[Poseidon]].<ref>[http://www.csun.edu/~hcfll004/mycen.html Adams, John Paul, ''Mycenean divinities''] – List of handouts for California State University Classics 315. Retrieved 7 March 2011.</ref><ref>[[R. S. P. Beekes]]. ''Etymological Dictionary of Greek'', Brill, 2009, p. 324.</ref> However, the ''dā'' element in the name of Demeter is not so simply equated with "earth" according to [[John Chadwick]].<ref>Chadwick, ''The Mycenaean World'', Cambridge University Press, 1976, p. 87) "Every Greek was aware of the maternal functions of Demeter; if her name bore the slightest resemblance to the Greek word for 'mother', it would inevitably have been deformed to emphasize that resemblance. [...] How did it escape transformation into ''*Gāmātēr'', a name transparent to any Greek speaker?" Compare the Latin transformation ''[[Jupiter (mythology)|Iuppiter]]'' and ''Diespiter'' vis-a-vis ''*Deus pater''.</ref><ref>{{LSJ|*dhmh/thr|Δημήτηρ|ref|mLSJ}}.</ref>
The element ''De''- may be connected with ''Deo'', an [[epithet]] of Demeter<ref>[[Orphic Hymn]] 40 to Demeter (translated by Thomas Taylor: "O universal mother Deo famed, august, the source of wealth and various names".</ref> probably derived from the Cretan word ''dea'' ({{lang|grc|δηά}}), Ionic ''zeia'' ({{lang|grc|ζειά}})—variously identified with [[emmer]], [[spelt]], [[rye]], or other grains by modern scholars—so that she is the Mother and the giver of food generally.<ref>Compare sanskr. yava, lit. yavai, Δά is probably derived from δέFα :Martin Nilsson, ''Geschichte der Griechischen Religion'', vol. I (Verlag C.H.Beck) pp 461-462.</ref><ref>[https://archive.org/stream/prolegomenatostu00harr#page/272/mode/2up Harisson, ''Prolegomena'', p.272]</ref> [[Anax|Wanax]] (''wa-na-ka'') was her male companion (Greek: Πάρεδρος, ''Paredros'') in [[Mycenaean religion|Mycenaean cult]].<ref>Dietrich, p.181</ref> The Arcadian cult links her to the god [[Poseidon]], who probably substituted the male companion of the [[Great Goddess]] ; Demeter may therefore be related to a [[Minoan civilization|Minoan]] [[Great Goddess]] ([[Cybele]]).<ref>Nilsson, 1967:444</ref>
An alternative Proto-Indo-European etymology comes through Potnia and [[Despoina]], where ''Des-'' represents a derivative of [[PIE]] ''*dem'' (house, dome), and Demeter is "mother of the house" (from [[PIE]] ''*dems-méh₂tēr'').<ref>Frisk, ''Griechisches Etymological Woerterbuch''. Entry 1271</ref>
== Agricultural deity == [[File:Didrachme de l'île de Paros.jpg|thumb|left|[[Greek drachma|Didrachme]] from Paros island, struck at the [[Cyclades]] and representing Demeter]] [[File:Склеп Деметры.JPG|thumb|A Greek [[fresco]] depicting the goddess Demeter, from [[Panticapaeum]] in the ancient [[Bosporan Kingdom]] (a [[client state]] of the [[Roman Empire]]), 1st century AD, [[Crimea]].]] According to the Athenian [[rhetorician]] [[Isocrates]], Demeter's greatest gifts to humankind were agriculture, particularly of cereals, and the Mysteries which give the initiate higher hopes in this life and the afterlife.<ref>[[Isocrates]], ''Panegyricus'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=Isoc.+4+27 4.28]: "When Demeter came to our land, in her wandering after the rape of Kore, and, being moved to kindness towards our ancestors by services which may not be told save to her initiates, gave these two gifts, the greatest in the world — the fruits of the earth, which have enabled us to rise above the life of the beasts, and the holy rite, which inspires in those who partake of it sweeter hopes regarding both the end of life and all eternity".</ref> These two gifts were intimately connected in Demeter's myths and mystery cults. In Hesiod, prayers to [[Zeus]]-Chthonios ([[chthonic]] Zeus) and Demeter help the crops grow full and strong.<ref>[[Hesiod]] ''Works and Days'', 465</ref> Demeter's emblem is the poppy, a bright red flower that grows among the barley.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Graves|first=Robert|title=Greek Gods and Heroes|publisher=Dell Laurel-Leaf|year=1960}}</ref>
In [[Hesiod]]'s [[Theogony]], Demeter is the daughter of [[Cronus]] and [[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]]. At the marriage of [[Cadmus]] and [[Harmonia (mythology)|Harmonia]], Demeter lured [[Iasion]] away from the other revelers. They had intercourse in a [[Ridge and furrow|ploughed furrow]] in [[Crete]], and she gave birth to two sons, [[Philomelus]] and [[Plutus|Ploutos]].<ref>''Odyssey'' 5.125; [[Theogony]] 969 ff.</ref> Her daughter by Zeus was [[Persephone]], Queen of the Underworld.<ref>Hesiod, ''Theogony'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+912&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0130 912]; [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0138%3Ahymn%3D2 ''Homeric Hymn to Demeter'' (2)]; Pausnias, ''Description of Greece'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Paus.%208.37.9&lang=original 8.37.9]</ref>
== Festivals and cults == {{Main article|Eleusinian Mysteries|Thesmophoria}}
Demeter's two major festivals were [[sacred mysteries]]. Her [[Thesmophoria]] festival (11–13 October) was women-only.<ref>Benko, Stephen, ''The virgin goddess: studies in the pagan and Christian roots of mariology,'' BRILL, 2004, note 111 on pp. 63 - 4, and p. 175.</ref> Her [[Eleusinian mysteries]] were open to initiates of any gender or social class. At the heart of both festivals were myths concerning Demeter as Mother and [[Persephone]] as her daughter.
==Mythology== === Demeter and Persephone ===<!-- link to section heading from article Sir Gawain and the Carle of Carlisle, section 'Regeneration'. --> [[File:Demeter in horse chariot w daughter kore 83d40m wikiC Tempio Y di Selinunte sec VIa.JPG|thumb|left|Demeter drives her horse-drawn chariot containing her daughter [[Persephone|Persephone-Kore]] at [[Selinunte]], Sicily, 6th century BC.]] Demeter's virgin daughter Persephone was abducted to the underworld by [[Hades]]. Demeter [[Agelasta|searched for her]] ceaselessly, preoccupied with her loss and her grief. The seasons halted; living things ceased their growth, then began to die.<ref>Karl Kerenyi, ''The Gods of the Greeks,'' 1951, pp.232 - 41 and notes 784 - 98.</ref> Faced with the extinction of all life on earth, [[Zeus]] sent his messenger [[Hermes]] to the underworld to bring Persephone back. [[Hades]] agreed to release her if she had eaten nothing while in his realm; but Persephone had eaten a small number of [[pomegranate]] [[seed]]s. This bound her to Hades and the underworld for certain months of every year, either the dry Mediterranean summer, when plant life is threatened by drought,<ref>As in Burkert, ''Greek Religion'' (Harvard, 1985) p. 160.</ref> or the autumn and winter.<ref>As in [[Porphyry (philosopher)|Porphyry]]<!--a reference is still missing--></ref> There are several variations on the basic myth. In the [[Homeric hymn]] to Demeter, [[Hecate]] assists in the search and later becomes Persephone's underworld attendant.<ref>[http://www.uh.edu/~cldue/texts/demeter.html Homer Hymn to Demeter, trans. Gregory Nagy, lines 50 - 60, 438 - 440.]</ref> In another, Persephone willingly and secretly eats the pomegranate seeds, thinking to deceive Hades, but is discovered and made to stay. Contrary to popular perception, Persephone's time in the underworld does not correspond with the unfruitful seasons of the ancient [[Greek calendar]], nor her return to the [[Upper World (Greek)|upper world]] with springtime.<ref>Graf, "Demeter" in ''Brill's New Pauly''</ref> Demeter's descent to retrieve Persephone from the underworld is connected to the [[Eleusinian Mysteries]].[[File:Demeter rejoiced, for her daughter was by her side.jpg|thumb|Demeter rejoiced, for her daughter was by her side.]]{{Clear|left}}
Demeter and her daughter '''Persephone''' were usually called:<ref>Martin Nilsson (1967) ''Die Geschichte der Griechische Religion'' pp.463, 477</ref> * '''The goddesses''', often distinguished as "the older" and "the younger" in [[Eleusis]]. * '''Demeters''', in [[Rhodes]] and [[Sparta]] * '''The thesmophoroi''', "the legislators" in the [[Thesmophoria]]. * '''The Great Goddesses''', in [[Arcadia (ancient region)|Arcadia]]. * '''The mistresses''' in [[Arcadia]].<ref name=Pausanias515>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]].''Description of Greece'' 5.15.4, 5, 6</ref> In [[Mycenaean civilization|Mycenaean]] [[Pylos]], Demeter and Persephone were probably called "queens" (wa-na-ssoi).<ref name=Mylonas159/>
The myth of the capture of Persephone seems to be pre-Greek. In the Greek version, Ploutos (πλούτος, wealth) represents the wealth of the corn that was stored in underground silos or ceramic jars (''pithoi''). Similar subterranean ''pithoi'' were used in ancient times for funerary practices. At the beginning of the autumn, when the corn of the old crop is laid on the fields, she ascends and is reunited with her mother Demeter, for at this time the old crop and the new meet each other.<ref>[https://sacred-texts.com/cla/gpr/gpr07.htm#page_48 Martin Nilsson, ''Greek Popular Religion''.] pp 48-50</ref>
According to the personal mythology of [[Robert Graves]],<ref>Graves' work on Greek myth was often criticized; see [[The White Goddess#Criticism]] and [[The Greek Myths#Reception|The Greek Myths]].</ref> Persephone is not only the younger self of Demeter,<ref>The idea that Kore (the maiden) is not Demeter's daughter, but Demeter's own younger self, was discussed much earlier than Graves, in [[Lewis Richard Farnell]] (1896), [https://books.google.com/books?id=FKVEsNO6wFYC&pg=PA121 ''The Cults of the Greek States'', volume 3, p.121.]</ref> she is in turn also one of three guises of the [[Triple deity|Triple Goddess]] – Kore (the youngest, the maiden, signifying green young grain), Persephone (in the middle, the nymph, signifying the ripe grain waiting to be harvested), and Hecate (the eldest of the three, the crone, the harvested grain), which to a certain extent reduces the name and role of Demeter to that of group name. Before her abduction, she is called Kore; and once taken she becomes Persephone ('she who brings destruction').<ref>Graves, Robert. ''The Greek Myths''. Penguin, 1990. {{ISBN|0-14-001026-2}}. 24. pp.94–95.</ref>
=== Demeter at Eleusis === [[File:Eleusis2.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Eleusinian mysteries|Eleusinian trio]]: [[Persephone]], [[Triptolemos]], and Demeter, on a marble [[bas-relief]] from [[Eleusis]], 440–430 BC]] [[File:Demeter MKL1888.png|left|thumb|Relief of Demeter in [[Pompeii]] referencing her ancient status of [[mother goddess]] and goddess of agriculture]] Demeter's search for her daughter Persephone took her to the palace of [[Celeus]], the King of [[Eleusis]] in [[Attica, Greece|Attica]]. She assumed the form of an old woman, and asked him for shelter. He took her in, to nurse [[Demophon of Eleusis|Demophon]] and [[Triptolemus]], his sons by [[Metanira]]. To reward his kindness, she planned to make Demophon immortal; she secretly anointed the boy with [[ambrosia]] and laid him in the flames of the hearth, to gradually burn away his mortal self. But Metanira walked in, saw her son in the fire and screamed in fright. Demeter abandoned the attempt. Instead, she taught Triptolemus the secrets of agriculture, and he in turn taught them to any who wished to learn them. Thus, humanity learned how to plant, grow and harvest grain. The myth has several versions; some are linked to figures such as [[Eleusis (mythology)|Eleusis]], [[Rarus]] and [[Trochilus (mythology)|Trochilus]]. The Demophon element may be based on an earlier folk tale.<ref>Nilsson (1940), p. 50: "The Demophon<!--Demophoon?--> story in Eleusis is based on an older folk-tale motif which has nothing to do with the Eleusinian Cult. It is introduced in order to let Demeter reveal herself in her divine shape".</ref>
===Demeter and Poseidon <!-- This section is linked from [[Epona]]; if changing this heading, change it there -->=== [[File:Demeter Altemps Inv8596.jpg|thumb|Roman copy after a Greek original from the 4th century BC, from the [[National Roman Museum]]]] Demeter and [[Poseidon]]'s names appear in the earliest scratched notes in [[Linear B]] found at [[Mycenae]] and Mycenaean [[Pylos]]; ''e-ne-si-da-o-ne'' (earth-shaker) for Poseidon, and ''si-to-po-ti-ni-ja'', who is probably related with Demeter.<ref>George Mylonas (1966), "Mycenae and the Mycenean world ". p.159. Princeton University Press</ref> Poseidon carries frequently the title ''wa-na-ka'' (''[[wanax]]'') in [[Linear B]] inscriptions, as king of the underworld, and his title '' E-ne-si-da-o-ne'' indicates his chthonic nature. In the cave of [[Amnisos]] (Crete) ''Enesidaon'' is related with the cult of [[Eileithyia]], the goddess of childbirth.<ref name= Dietriech181>Dietrich pp. 181-185</ref> She was related with the annual birth of the divine child.<ref>Dietrich pp. 141</ref> During the Bronze Age, a goddess of nature, dominated both in Minoan and Mycenean cult, and ''Wanax'' (''wa-na-ka'') was her male companion (paredros) in Mycenean cult.<ref name=Dietriech181/> She and her paredros survived in the [[Eleusinian mysteries|Eleusinian cult]], where the following words were uttered : " Mighty Potnia bore a strong son"<ref>Dietrich:166-167</ref> However, there is no evidence that originally the name of [[Potnia]] was Demeter.
Tablets from [[Pylos]] record sacrificial goods destined for "the Two Queens and Poseidon" ("to the Two Queens and the King" :''wa-na-ssoi'', ''wa-na-ka-te''). The "Two Queens" may be related with Demeter and [[Persephone]], or their precursors, goddesses who were not associated with Poseidon in later periods.<ref name=Mylonas159/> An exception is the myth of isolated [[Arcadia]] in southern Greece. [[Despoina]], is daughter of Demeter and [[Poseidon]] ''Hippios'', Horse-Poseidon. These myths seem to be connected with the first Greek-speaking people who came from the north during the [[Bronze age]]. Poseidon represents the river spirit of the underworld and he appears as a horse as it often happens in northern-European folklore. He pursues the mare-Demeter and she bears one daughter who obviously originally had the form or the shape of a mare too. Demeter and Despoina were closely connected with springs and animals, related to Poseidon as a God of waters and especially with [[Artemis]], the mistress of the animals and the goddess of, among others, the Hunt.
Demeter as mare-goddess was pursued by Poseidon, and hid from him among the horses of King [[Onkios]], but could not conceal her divinity. In the form of a stallion, Poseidon caught and covered her. Demeter was furious ([[erinys]]) at Poseidon's assault; in this furious form, she is known as Demeter Erinys. But she washed away her anger in the River [[Ladon (river)|Ladon]], becoming ''Demeter Lousia'', the "bathed Demeter".<ref>Other ritually bathed goddesses were Argive [[Hera]] and [[Cybele]]; [[Aphrodite]] renewed her own powers bathing herself in the sea.</ref> "In her alliance with Poseidon," [[Karl Kerenyi]] noted,<ref>Kerenyi, ''The Gods of the Greeks'', 1951:185.</ref> "she was [[Gaia (mythology)|Earth]], who bears plants and beasts, and could therefore assume the shape of an ear of [[grain]] or a mare." She bore a daughter [[Despoina]] ({{lang|grc|Δέσποινα}}: the "Mistress"), whose name should not be uttered outside the Arcadian [[Sacred mysteries|Mysteries]],<ref>"In Arcadia she was also a second goddess in the Mysteries of her daughter, the unnameable, who was invoked only as 'Despoina', the 'Mistress'" ([[Karl Kerenyi]], ''Eleusis: Archetypal Image of Mother and Daughter''(Princeton University Press) 1967:31f, instancing Pausanias, viii.37.9.</ref> and a horse named [[Arion (mythology)|Arion]], with a black mane and tail.
In [[Arcadia]], Demeter's mare-form was worshiped into historical times. Her ''[[xoanon]]'' of Phigaleia shows how the local cult interpreted her: a Medusa type with a horse's head with snaky hair, holding a dove and a dolphin, probably representing her power over air and water.<ref>L. H. Jeffery (1976). ''Archaic Greece: The Greek city states c. 800-500 B.C.'' (Ernest Benn Limited) p 23 {{ISBN|0-510-03271-0}}</ref>
{{Quotation|The second mountain, Mt. Elaios, is about 30 stades from [[Phigalia|Phigaleia]], and has a cave sacred to Demeter Melaine ["Black"]... the Phigalians say, they accounted the cave sacred to Demeter, and set up a [[Xoanon|wooden image]] in it. The image was made in the following fashion: it was seated on a rock, and was like a woman in all respects save the head. She had the head and hair of a horse, and serpents and other beasts grew out of her head. Her [[Chiton (costume)|chiton]] reached right to her feet, and she held a dolphin in one hand, a dove in the other. Why they made the ''[[xoanon]]'' like this should be clear to any intelligent man who is versed in tradition. They say they named her Black because the goddess wore black clothing. However, they cannot remember who made this xoanon or how it caught fire; but when it was destroyed the Phigalians gave no new image to the goddess and largely neglected her festivals and sacrifices, until finally barrenness fell upon the land.|[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]]| Description of Greece 8.42.1ff.}}
<!--much of this is duplicative and uneditable:===Corn-Mother and Mother-Earth=== In epic poetry and [[Hesiod]]'s ''[[Theogony]]'', Demeter is the Corn-Mother, the goddess of cereals who provides grain for bread and blesses its harvesters. This was her main function at [[Eleusis]], and became panhellenic. In [[Cyprus]], "grain-harvesting" was ''damatrizein''. The main theme in the [[Eleusinian]] mysteries was the reunion of [[Persephone]] with her mother Demeter, when new crops were reunited with the old seed, a form of eternity. However, some cults interpreted Demeter as Mother Earth. At Phigaleia in [[Arcadia]], she was represented as an archaised [[Medusa]] type, horse-headed and snake-haired, holding a dove and dolphin, perhaps to symbolize her power over air and water. In the cult of Flya, she was worshiped as [[Anesidora]] (one who sends up gifts from the underworld) and in Sparta as Demeter-Chthonia ([[chthonic]] Demeter).<ref>[[Pausanias]] I 31,4- III 14,5</ref> This can explain the name Demetrioi that the Athenians gave to the dead, and probably reflects an ancient cult of the dead, linked to the agrarian-belief that a new life would sprout from the dead body, as a new plant arises from buried seed. This was probably a belief shared by initiates in Demeter's mysteries, as interpreted by [[Pindar]]: "Happy is he who has seen what exists under the earth, because he knows not only the end of life, but also his beginning that the Gods will give". In antiquity Demeter was also ''zeidoros arοura'', the Homeric "Mother Earth [[arura|arοura]]" who gave the gift of cereals (''zeai'' or ''deai'').<ref>Martin Nilsson, (1967), ''Die Geschichte der Griechische Religion'', C.F.Beck Verlag Munchen, pp 462, 466, 675-676.</ref>-->
== Titles and functions == [[File:Eleusinian hydria Antikensammlung Berlin 1984.46 n2.jpg|thumb|left|Demeter, enthroned and extending her hand in a benediction toward the kneeling [[Metaneira]], who offers the [[wikt:triune|triune]] wheat ({{circa|340 {{small|BC}}}})]] Demeter's [[epithet]]s show her many religious functions. She was the "Corn-Mother" who blesses the harvesters. Some cults interpreted her as "Mother-Earth". Demeter may be linked to goddess-cults of [[Minoan civilization|Minoan]] [[Crete]], and embody aspects of a pre-Hellenic [[Mother Goddess]].<ref>A [[Linear A]] inscription can tentatively be read as DA-MA-TE (KY Za 2), which is possibly the name of the Mother Goddess. [http://www.teicrete.gr/arkalochori/linear-inscription.php]</ref> <!--Linear A is not deciphered: In the [[Linear A]] ([[Minoan civilization|Minoan]]) inscriptions appears often the word ''asasarame'',"mistress" that seems to accompany the names of some goddesses.<ref>Similar with [[Hittite language|Hittite]] ''išhaššara'',"lady" or "mistress".Palmer sees -me as an [[PI]] possesiv-pronoun and interprets it as "my lady" similar with the Hittite ''išhaššaraŝamiŝ''.The name does not seem to have [[PIE]] origin, compare [[Ishara]]-[[Ishtar]]:F.Schachermeyer (1964).''Die Minoische Kultur des alten Kreta''.W.Kohlhammer Verlag Stuttgart. p 263</ref>--> It is possible that the title "Mistress of the labyrinth", which appears in a [[Linear B]] inscription, belonged originally to ''Sito'' ("[she] of the grain"), the [[Mother goddess|Great Mother Demeter]] and that in the [[Eleusinian mysteries]] this title was kept by her daughter [[Persephone]] (Kore or [[Despoina]]).<ref>R.Wunderlich (1975),''The secret of Creta''.Souvenir Press Ltd.London p 319</ref> However, there is no evidence that the name of [[Potnia]] in [[Eleusis]] was originally Demeter. Her other epithets include:
[[File:Triptolemos Louvre G187.jpg|thumb|left|[[Triptolemus]], Demeter and [[Persephone]] by the Triptolemos-painter, c. 470 BC, [[Louvre]]]] * [[Aganippe]] ("the Mare who destroys mercifully", "Night-Mare") * [[Potnia]] ("mistress") in the ''[[Homeric Hymns|Homeric Hymn to Demeter]]''. [[Hera]] especially, but also [[Artemis]] and [[Athena]], are addressed as "potnia" as well. * [[Despoina]] ("mistress of the house"), a Greek word similar to the [[Mycenaean language|Mycenean]] ''potnia''. This title was also applied to Persephone, [[Aphrodite]] and [[Hecate]]. * [[Thesmophoria|Thesmophoros]] ("giver of customs" or even "legislator"), a role that links her to the even more ancient goddess [[Themis]],<ref name=Finley78 /> derived from ''thesmos'', the unwritten law.<ref>L. H. Jeffery (1976). ''Archaic Greece: The Greek city states c. 800-500 B.C.'' (Ernest Benn Limited) p. 42 {{ISBN|0-510-03271-0}}</ref> This title was connected with the [[Thesmophoria]], a festival of secret women-only rituals in [[History of Athens|Athens]] connected with marriage customs. * [[Erinyes|Erinys]] ("implacable"),<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]] 8.25.50</ref> with a function similar with the function of the avenging [[Dike (mythology)|Dike]] (Justice), goddess of moral justice based on custom rules who represents the divine retribution,<ref>C.M. Bowra (1957), ''The Greek Experience''(1957:87, 169).</ref> and the [[Erinyes]], female ancient [[chthonic]] deities of vengeance and implacable agents of retribution. * [[Chloe]] ("the green shoot"),<ref>Pausanias 1.22.3.</ref> that invokes her powers of ever-returning fertility, as does Chthonia. * [[chthonic|Chthonia]] ("in the ground"), [[chthonic]] Demeter in Sparta.<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]] 3.14.5</ref> * Anesidora ("sending up gifts from the earth") applied to Demeter in Pausanias 1.31.4, also appears inscribed on an Attic ceramic a name for [[Pandora]] on her jar. There was a temple of Demeter under this name in [[Phlius]] in [[Attica]].<ref>Anesidora: inscribed against her figure on a [[White ground technique|white-ground]] ''[[Kylix (drinking cup)|kylix]]'' in the British Museum, B.M. 1881,0528.1, from Nola, painted by the Tarquinia painter, ''ca'' 470–460 BC ([https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/search_object_details.aspx?objectid=461511&partid=1&searchText=Anesidora+Nola+Tarquinia&fromADBC=ad&toADBC=ad&numpages=10&orig=%2fresearch%2fsearch_the_collection_database.aspx&currentPage=1 British Museum on-line catalogue entry])</ref><ref>[[Hesychius of Alexandria]] ''s.v.''</ref><ref>[[Scholiast]], ''On [[Theocritus]]'' ii. 12.</ref> * [[Europa (mythology)|Europa]] ("broad face or eyes") at [[Livadeia]] of [[Boeotia]]. She was the nurse of [[Trophonios]] to whom a [[chthonic]] cult and [[oracle]] was dedicated.<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]].''Guide to Greece''.9.39.2-5</ref> *Kidaria in the mysteries of Pheneos in Arcadia<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]] 8.13.13</ref> where the priest put on the mask of Demeter kept in a secret place. It seems that the cult was connected with the underworld and with an agrarian magic.<ref>Martin Nilsson (1967).''Die Geschichte der Griechiesche Religion'' Vol. I pp 477-478.</ref> Demeter might also be invoked in the guises of: * Malophoros ("apple-bearer" or "sheep-bearer", Pausanias 1.44.3) * Lusia ("bathing", Pausanias 8.25.8) * Thermasia ("warmth", Pausanias 2.34.6) * Achaea, the name by which she was worshipped at [[Athens]] by the Gephyraeans who had emigrated from [[Boeotia]].<ref>[[Herodotus]], v. 61; [[Plutarch]] ''Isis et Osiris'' p. 378, d</ref><ref name="dgrbm">{{Cite book | last = Smith | first = William | author-link = William Smith (lexicographer) | contribution = Achaea (1) | editor-last = Rachel | editor-first = William | title = [[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology]] | volume = 1 | page = 8 | publisher = | place = Boston | year = 1867 | contribution-url = http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/0017.html | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref>
* [[Poppy goddess]]:
[[Theocritus]], wrote of an earlier role of Demeter as a poppy goddess: :''For the Greeks Demeter was still a poppy goddess'' :''Bearing sheaves and poppies in both hands.'' — ''Idyll'' vii.157
In a clay statuette from Gazi (Heraklion Museum, Kereny 1976 fig 15), the Minoan [[Papaver somniferum|poppy]] goddess wears the seed capsules, sources of nourishment and narcosis, in her diadem. "It seems probable that the Great [[Mother Goddess]], who bore the names Rhea and Demeter, brought the poppy with her from her Cretan cult to [[Eleusinian mysteries|Eleusis]], and it is certain that in the Cretan cult sphere, [[opium]] was prepared from poppies" (Kerenyi 1976, p 24).
== Cult places == [[File:Demeter figurine - Museo Archeologico Regionale - Agrigento - Italy 2015 (2).JPG|thumb|left|Terracotta Demeter figurine, Sanctuary of the Underworld Divinities, Akragas, 550–500 BC]] [[File:Marble Statue of Demeter.jpg|thumb|[[Demeter of Knidos]], [[Hellenistic]] marble sculpture, around 350 BC]] Major [[cult (religion)|cults]] to Demeter are known at [[Eleusis]] in [[Attica]], Hermion (in [[Crete]]), [[Megara]], Celeae, [[Lerna]], Aegila, [[Munychia]], [[Ancient Corinth|Corinth]], [[Delos]], [[Priene]], [[Agrigento|Akragas]], [[Iasos]], [[Pergamon]], [[Selinus]], [[Tegea]], [[Thoricus]], Dion (in Macedonia)<ref>Cohen, A, Art in the Era of Alexander the Great: Paradigms of Manhood and Their Cultural Traditions, Cambridge University Press, 2010, p. 213. [https://books.google.com/books?id=nX8F_ZV83vUC&pg=PA213 Googlebook preview]</ref> [[Lycosura|Lykosoura]], [[Mesembria (Zone)|Mesembria]], [[Enna]] (Sicily), and [[Samothrace]].
An ancient [[Amphictyony]], probably the earliest centred on the cult of Demeter at [[Anthele]] (Ἀνθήλη), which lay on the coast of [[Malis]] south of Thessaly. This was the locality of Thermopylae.<ref name=Jeffery72>L. H. Jeffery (1976) ''Archaic Greece: The City States c. 700–500 BC''. Ernest Benn Ltd., London & Tonbridge pp. 72, 73, 78 {{ISBN|0-510-03271-0}}</ref><ref>The Parian marble. Entry No 5: "When [[Amphictyon]] son of [[Hellen]] became king of Thermopylae brought together those living round the temple and named them ''Amphictyones''; [http://www.ashmolean.org/ash/faqs/q004/q004008.html]</ref>
After the "First Sacred War", the Anthelan body was known thenceforth as the [[Amphictyonic League|Delphic Amphictyony]]<ref name=Jeffery72/>
Demeter of Mysia had a seven-day festival at Pellené in [[Arcadia]].<ref>Pausanias, 7. 27, 9.</ref> Pausanias passed the shrine to Demeter at Mysia on the road from [[Mycenae]] to [[Argos]] but all he could draw out to explain the archaic name was a myth of an eponymous [[Mysius]] who venerated Demeter.{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}
[[File:Whitehead Coins of the Punjab Museum Plate XI Azes Demeter and Hermes.jpg|thumb|center|[[Azes]] coin in [[India]], with Demeter and [[Hermes]], 1st century BC]]

== Consorts and children == {{Div col}} #[[Zeus]] ##[[Persephone]] #[[Poseidon]] ##[[Despoina]] ##[[Arion (mythology)|Arion]] #[[Iasion]] ##[[Plutus]] ##[[Philomelus]] #[[Carmanor (deity)|Karmanor]] ##[[Eubuleus]] ##[[Chrysothemis]] #[[Triptolemus]] ##[[Amphitheus I]] #[[Oceanus]] ##Dmia<ref>[[Hesychius of Alexandria]], s. v.</ref> {{Div col end}}
== Portrayals == * Demeter was frequently associated with images of the harvest, including flowers, fruit, and grain. She was also sometimes pictured with her daughter Persephone. * The Black Demeter, a sculpture made by [[Onatas]]. * Demeter is not generally portrayed with a consort: the exception is Iasion, the youth of Crete who lay with Demeter in a thrice-ploughed field, and was sacrificed afterwards by a jealous Zeus with a thunderbolt. * Demeter is assigned the zodiac constellation Virgo the Virgin by Marcus Manilius in his 1st century Roman work Astronomicon. In art, constellation Virgo holds Spica, a sheaf of wheat in her hand and sits beside constellation Leo the Lion. {{Citation needed|date=July 2013}}
== See also == {{Portal|Greek mythology|Hellenismos}} * [[Eleusinian Mysteries]] * [[1108 Demeter]], a [[asteroid belt|main belt]] [[asteroid]] 26 km in diameter, which was discovered in 1929 by [[Karl Wilhelm Reinmuth]] at [[Heidelberg]]. * [[Despoina]] * [[Greek mythology in popular culture#Demeter|Greek mythology in popular culture]] * [[Osiris myth|Isis and Osiris]] * [[Poppy goddess]] * [[Potnia]] * [[Hades]] * [[Law of Demeter]], a software design guideline named in honor of Demeter. * [[Ningishzida]], an earlier Mesopotamian deity connected with vegetation and the underworld

revision.comment: Adding 0 [[arXiv|arxiv eprint(s)]], 4 [[bibcode|bibcode(s)]] and 0 [[digital object identifier|doi(s)]]. Did it miss something? Report bugs, errors, and suggestions at [[User talk:Bibcode Bot]]
revision.text:
The '''Dole effect''', named after [[Malcolm Dole]], describes an inequality in the ratio of the heavy [[isotope]] [[Oxygen-18|<sup>18</sup>O]] (a "standard" [[oxygen]] atom with two additional [[neutron]]s) to the lighter <sup>16</sup>O, measured in the [[atmosphere]] and seawater. This ratio is usually denoted [[δ18O|δ<sup>18</sup>O]].
It was noticed in 1935<ref>{{cite journal |last=Dole |first=[[Malcolm Dole|Malcolm]] |authorlink= |year=1936 |title=The Relative Atomic Weight of Oxygen in Water and in Air |journal=Journal of Chemical Physics |volume=4 |issue=4 |pages=268–275 |doi=10.1063/1.1749834 |url= |bibcode=1936JChPh...4..268D }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Morita |first=N. |authorlink= |year=1935 |title=The increased density of air oxygen relative to water oxygen |journal=J. Chem. Soc. Japan |volume=56 |issue= |pages=1291 |url= }}</ref> that air contained more <sup>18</sup>O than seawater; this was quantified in 1975 to 23.5‰,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kroopnick |first=P. |authorlink= |author2=Craig, H. |year=1972 |title=Atmospheric Oxygen: Isotopic Composition and Solubility Fractionation |journal=Science |volume=175 |issue=4017 |pages=54–55 |doi=10.1126/science.175.4017.54 |url= |pmid=17833979 |bibcode=1972Sci...175...54K }}</ref> but later refined as 23.88‰ in 2005.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Barkan |first=E. |authorlink= |author2=Luz, B. |year=2005 |title=High precision measurements of <sup>17</sup>O/<sup>16</sup>O and <sup>18</sup>O/<sup>16</sup>O ratios in H<sub>2</sub>O |journal=Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. |volume=19 |pages=3737–3742 |doi=10.1002/rcm.2250 |url= }}</ref> The imbalance arises mainly as a result of [[Plant respiration|respiration in plant]]s and [[Respiration (physiology)|in animals]]. Due to [[thermodynamics]] of isotope reactions,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Urey |first=H.C. |authorlink= |year=1947 |title=The thermodynamic properties of isotopic substances |journal=J. Chem. Soc. |volume= |issue= |pages=562–581 |doi=10.1039/JR9470000562 |url= |pmid= }}</ref> respiration removes the lighter — hence more reactive — <sup>16</sup>O in preference to <sup>18</sup>O, increasing the relative amount of <sup>18</sup>O in the atmosphere.
The inequality is balanced by [[photosynthesis]]. Photosynthesis emits oxygen with the same isotopic composition (i.e. [[δ18O|the ratio between <sup>18</sup>O and <sup>16</sup>O]]) as the water (H<sub>2</sub>O) used in the reaction,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Guy |first=Robert D. |authorlink= |year=1989 |title=Differential fractionation of oxygen isotopes by cyanide-resistant and cyanide-sensitive respiration in plants |journal=Planta |volume=177 |issue= 4|pages=483–491 |doi=10.1007/BF00392616 |url= |display-authors=etal |pmid=24212490}}</ref> which is independent of the atmospheric ratio. Thus when atmospheric <sup>18</sup>O levels are high enough, photosynthesis will act as a reducing factor. However, as a complicating factor, the degree of fractionation (i.e. change in isotope ratio) occurring due to photosynthesis is not ''entirely'' dependent on the water drawn up by the plant, as fractionation can occur as a result of preferential evaporation of {{clarify span|H<sub>2</sub><sup>16</sup>O - water bearing lighter oxygen isotopes,|strange punctuation; if it means only O-16, then why ''isotopeS''?|date=March 2014}} and other small but significant processes.
==Use of the Dole effect== Since evaporation causes oceanic and terrestrial waters to have a different ratio of <sup>18</sup>O to <sup>16</sup>O, the Dole effect will reflect the relevant importances of land-based and marine photosynthesis. The complete removal of land-based productivity would result {{clarify span|in a Dole effect shift of -2-3‰ from the current value of 23.5‰|does it mean ''in a negative 2–3‰ shift from the current Dole effect value of 23.5‰''?|date=March 2014}}.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Bender |first=M. |authorlink= |author2=Sowers, T. |author3=Labeyrie, L. |year=1994 |title=The Dole effect and its variations during the last 130,000 years as measured in the Vostok ice core |journal=Global Biogeochemical Cycles |volume=8 |issue= 3|pages=363–376 |url= |doi=10.1029/94GB00724 |bibcode=1994GBioC...8..363B}}</ref>
The stability (to within 0.5‰) of the atmospheric <sup>18</sup>O to <sup>16</sup>O ratio with respect to sea surface waters since the [[interglacial|last interglacial]] (the last 130 000 years), as derived from ice cores, suggests that terrestrial and marine productivity have varied together during this time period.
Millennial variations of the Dole effect were found to be related to abrupt climate change events in the North Atlantic region during the last 60 kyr.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Severinghaus | first = J.P. |author2=Beaudette, R. |author3=Headly, M.A. |author4=Taylor, K. |author5=Brook, E.J. | year = 2009 | title = Oxygen-18 of O<sub>2</sub> records the impact of abrupt climate change on the terrestrial biosphere | journal = Science | volume = 324 | issue = 5933 | pages = 1431–1434 | doi = 10.1126/science.1169473|bibcode=2009Sci...324.1431S }}</ref> High correlations of the Dole effect to [[speleothem]] δ<sup>18</sup>O, an indicator for [[monsoon]] precipitation, suggest that it is subject to changes in low-latitude terrestrial productivity. Orbital scale variations of the Dole effect, characterized by periods of 20-100 kyr, respond strongly to Earth's orbital [[Orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] and [[Axial precession (astronomy) |precession]], but not [[obliquity]].<ref>{{cite journal | last = Landais | first = A. |author2=Dreyfus, G. |author3=Capron, E. |author4=Masson-Delmotte, V. |author5=Sanchez-Goñi, M.F. |author6=Desprat, S. |author7=Hoffmann, G. |author8=Jouzel, J. |author9=Leuenberger, M. |author10= Johnsen, S. | year = 2010 | title = What drives the millennial and orbital variations of δ<sup>18</sup>O<sub>atm</sub> | journal = Quaternary Sci. Rev. | volume = 29 | pages = 235–246 | doi = 10.1016/j.quascirev.2009.07.005|bibcode=2010QSRv...29..235L }}</ref>
The Dole effect can also be applied as a [[Flow tracer|tracer]] in sea water, with slight variations in chemistry being used to track a discrete "parcel" of water and determine its age.
==See also== *[[Isotopes of oxygen]]

[[File:Dry river 2.jpg|thumb|A dried-up river in [[Ehrwald]]]] An '''endangered river''' is one which has the potential to partly or fully dry up, or one that is thought to have [[ecology|ecological]] issues now or in the near future.<ref name="WWF" /> Some such issues are natural while others are the direct result of human development. Organisations including the [[World Wildlife Fund]] (WWF) have published lists of rivers at risk. The WWF's 2007 list featured the [[Danube]], the [[Nile]], and the [[Rio Grande]] amongst others, stating that these "once great rivers" are in danger and "can no longer be assured of reaching the sea unhindered".<ref name="WWF" /> The US [[National Park Service]] reported in 2015 that part of the Rio Grande "often lies dry".<ref name="NPS" /> Dangers may be the result of the natural change of conditions in the local environment but many are due to human development projects such as [[dam]]s and [[irrigation]]. Humans have also caused significant [[water pollution]] which endangers life which relies upon the water source.
==Importance== According to the [[World Resources Institute]] (WRI) [[river basin]]s are "indispensable resources for billions of people, companies, farms, and ecosystems" but many suffer from "water stress". It states that numerous major rivers around the world have become depleted to the point that they can fail to reach their destinations.<ref name="WRI14" /> [[Water scarcity]] is a danger to all the life that depends on the source.
==Dangers to rivers== [[File:Beaver dam in Tierra del Fuego.jpg|thumb|[[Beaver eradication in Tierra del Fuego|Beavers from North America constitute an invasive species]] in [[Tierra del Fuego]].]] [[River]]s face many dangers, both natural and manmade. [[Climate change]] can have a significant impact on rivers, both positive and negative. This could be seen itself as an indirect result of human developments. An area which has a reduction in rainfall or an increase in temperature can make a river fully or partially dry out. This often means that the water can no longer reach its [[river mouth|mouth]].<ref name="WWF" />
The [[flora]] and [[fauna]] of an area can face change and can have a substantial impact on landscape and local ecology.<ref name="WWF" /> [[Invasive species]] can move into an area or be introduced by humans. One particular example of the latter is the case of beavers being introduced into [[Tierra del Fuego]] in 1946. While only 20 animals were transplanted into the area they quickly reproduced with no natural predator to curb numbers. Their effect on the area, through the damaging gnawing of trees and the building of [[beaver dam|their dams]], has been significant enough that humans continue an attempt to undo their mistake with [[Beaver eradication in Tierra del Fuego|a program of beaver eradication]]. The ponds created by the beavers, which now number in the tens of thousands, have greatly contributed to the amount of organic matter retained by the rivers which then causes more problems downstream.<ref name="SA14" />
===Specific human factors=== Human interference in the form of [[river engineering]] can redirect the flow of the water using [[dam]]s or channelisation.<ref name="WWF" /> The increasing demand from [[irrigation|irrigated]] agriculture, continued industrialisation, and residential use heavily impacts upon the health of river systems. This means that many areas face high levels of "baseline water stress".<ref name="WRI14" /> Rivers can be cut off from their [[floodplain]]s and their normal route can be changed or disrupted significantly. If improperly managed this can have a devastating effect on the surrounding area and endanger the plants and animals that depend on them, including humans. [[Water pollution]] is another artificial danger which can be a serious threat to wildlife and human health.<ref name="WWF" /> The [[Colorado River]] runs from the [[Rocky Mountain National Park]] in [[Colorado]] through four other states, parts of [[Mexico]], and then on to the [[Gulf of California]]. Due to the human demands for water very little reaches Mexico and what does is often polluted.<ref name="MNNcol" /> The [[Teesta River]] faces similar issues. The river flows through India and into Bangladesh, but India's water demands led to the part of the river in Bangladesh to dry up in 2018. If the situation continues it could be catastrophic for the local ecosystem.<ref name="DT18" />
[[Image:Big Bend National Park - Rio Grande riverbed with cracked mud.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Rio Grande]] occasionally runs dry in [[Big Bend National Park]].]] The [[Rio Grande Project]] was an irrigation, [[hydroelectricity]], [[flood control]], and [[Interbasin transfer|interbasin water transfer]] project serving the upper [[Rio Grande]] basin in the southwestern United States. It was completed in 1952 and has had a significant impact on the surrounding area. In the past, the river was wide, deep and fast-flowing in its section through Texas, where it forms a large part of the [[Mexico – United States border]]. [[Illegal immigration to the United States|Illegal immigrants]] once had to swim across the river at the border, but with the river so low immigrants need only wade across for most of the year. After leaving [[El Paso, Texas|El Paso]] the Rio Grande often runs dry because so much water has been diverted away for human use.<ref name="NPS" /> Other than extensive diversions, exotic introduced, fast-growing and water-consuming plants, such as [[Eichhornia crassipes|water hyacinth]] and [[hydrilla]], are also leading to reduced flows. The United States government has recently attempted to slow or stop the progress of these weeds by [[Biological pest control|introducing]] insects and fish that feed on the invasive plants.<ref name="bnet" />
==Reports== [[File:Citarum River pollution, 2009.jpg|thumb|Pollution on the [[Citarum River]]]] In 2014 a [[Channel 4]] report suggested that the [[Indonesia]]n [[Citarum River]], forty miles east of [[Jakarta]], may be the most polluted river in the world. Running from [[Wayang-Windu|Mount Wayang]] to the [[Java Sea]], there are over 30 million residents who rely on the river. Rapid [[industrialisation]] has had such a harmful effect that the river's surface cannot be seen for the waste and detritus floating on top of it.<ref name="Teleg14" />
===World Wildlife Fund report=== The WWF published on their website the "10 Rivers most at Risk", a report from March 2007. They based their criteria on major rivers which already suffer or are particularly likely in the future to suffer from six key threats: dams and infrastructure, excessive water extraction, climate change, invasive species, over-fishing, and pollution. They noted that some of the greatest rivers "can no longer be assured of reaching the sea unhindered". The ten rivers which most concerned them are:<ref name="WWF" /> {{columns-list| *[[Salween River]] *[[Río de la Plata|La Plata]] *[[Danube]] *[[Rio Grande]] *[[Ganges]] *[[Murray–Darling basin]] *[[Indus River]] *[[Nile]] *[[Yangtze]] *[[Mekong]] }}
===American Rivers reports=== Each year [[American Rivers]] publishes a list containing ten of "America's Most Endangered Rivers". In 2018 its criteria focused on "threats [to rivers] from the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]]" and they selected the [[Sunflower River|Big Sunflower River]] as the one most endangered using their criteria. The river is one of the main [[tributary|tributaries]] of the [[Yazoo River]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Mississippi]] but is threatened by the Yazoo Backwater Area Pumping Plant project which they say has the potential to damage 200,000 acres of important [[wetland]].<ref name="AR2018" />
===World Resources Institute project=== The World Resources Institute's Aqueduct project evaluated, mapped, and rated the state of the water supplies for 100 river basins in areas of high population. Their list highlighted the dangers to the [[Qom (River)|Qom River]], [[Yongding River]], [[Brantas River]], and [[Hari (Afghanistan)|Heray Rud River]] amongst others.<ref name="WRI14" />
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name="MNNcol"> {{cite web |title=8 lakes and rivers that are drying up |surname=Gunther |first=Shea |publisher=[[Mother Nature Network]] |url=https://www.mnn.com/earth-matters/wilderness-resources/photos/7-lakes-and-rivers-that-are-drying-up/colorado-river |date=20 May 2016 |accessdate=25 April 2018 }} </ref>
<ref name="AR2018"> {{cite web |title=America's Most Endangered Rivers 2018 |publisher=American Rivers |url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/american-rivers-website/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/09164515/MER2018_FullReport_04022018_reducedsize2.pdf |date=20 May 2016 |page=3–4 |accessdate=25 April 2018 }} </ref>
<ref name="WWF"> {{cite web |title=10 Rivers most at Risk |publisher=[[World Wildlife Fund]] |url=https://www.wwf.org.uk/sites/default/files/2007-01/worldstop10riversatrisk.pdf |date=March 2007 |accessdate=8 May 2018 }} </ref>
<ref name="Teleg14"> {{cite news |title=Citarum, the most polluted river in the world? |work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/environment/10761077/Citarum-the-most-polluted-river-in-the-world.html |date=11 April 2014 |surname=Yallop |first=Olivia |accessdate=25 April 2018 }} </ref>

<ref name="NPS"> {{cite web |title=The Rio Grande |publisher=[[National Park Service]] |url=https://www.nps.gov/bibe/learn/nature/riogrand.htm |date=24 February 2015 |accessdate=26 May 2018 }} </ref> }}
[[Category:Rivers]] [[Category:Ecology]]

{{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} [[File:NZPrimaryEnergy2014.png|thumb|right|400px|New Zealand primary energy supply 2014. Source: MBIE Energy in New Zealand 2014{{cite web|url=http://www.mbie.govt.nz/info-services/sectors-industries/energy/energy-data-modelling/publications/energy-in-new-zealand| title=Energy in New Zealand| date=August 2015| publisher=[[Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment|MBIE]]}}]] Despite abundant natural resources and a relatively small population, [[New Zealand]] is a net importer of energy, in the form of [[petroleum]] products. The ratio of non-renewable and [[renewable energy]] sources was fairly consistent from 1975 to 2008, with about 70 percent of primary energy supply coming from [[hydrocarbon]] fuels. This ratio decreased to about 60 percent in 2014. The proportion of non-renewable energy varies annually, depending on water flows into hydro-electricity lakes and demand for energy.{{cite book| publisher = Ministry for the Environment| isbn = 978-0-478-30191-5 | last=MfE| series=ME 847| title=Environment New Zealand 2007| contribution=Chapter 5 Energy Current pressures and trends |url= http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/environmental-reporting/environment-new-zealand-2007/chapter-5-energy/ |location=Wellington, N.Z. |date=December 2007}} In 2014, approximately 60% of [[primary energy]] was from non-renewable hydrocarbon fuels and 40% was from renewable sources. In 2007 energy consumption per capita was 120 gigajoules. Per capita energy consumption had increased 8 per cent since 1998. New Zealand uses more energy per capita than 17 of 30 OECD countries.{{cite web |url= http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/energy-environmental-reporting/environmental-report-card-energy-supply-and-demand/ |title=Environmental Report Card Energy Supply and Demand |first= |last=MfE |work= INFO 421 |publisher= Ministry for the Environment |date=July 2009 |accessdate=30 May 2012}} New Zealand is one of 13 OECD countries that does not operate [[nuclear power plant|nuclear power station]]s. From 1994 to 2014, the energy intensity of the economy per unit of GDP declined by 24 percent to 2.67 MJ/$. A contributing factor is the growth of relatively less energy-intensive service industries.{{cite web| url= http://www.stats.govt.nz/browse_for_stats/environment/sustainable_development/key-findings-2010/efficiency-how-efficiently-we-using-resources.aspx#energy| title=Key Findings on New Zealand's Progress Using a Sustainable Development Approach| work= Statistics New Zealand| year=2010| accessdate=21 April 2012}} == Energy supply == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:right;" |+ New Zealand primary energy 1990–2017 ([[Petajoule|PJ]]){{cite web |title= Energy in New Zealand 2018 |url= https://www.mbie.govt.nz/info-services/sectors-industries/energy/energy-data-modelling/publications/energy-in-new-zealand/documents-images/energy-in-nz-2018.pdf |publisher= Ministry of Business, Innovation & Employment |accessdate= 4 November 2018}} |- ! style="text-align:right;"|'''908.46''' || style="text-align:right;"|'''931.77''' |} === Coal === {{main|Mining in New Zealand}} [[File:NZCoalProduction.png|thumb|right|400px|New Zealand Coal Production, 1878 - 2014.]] Coal is produced from 18 opencast mines.{{cite web| url=https://www.nzpam.govt.nz/our-industry/nz-minerals/minerals-data/coal/operating-mines/| title=Operating coal mine production figures| publisher=New Zealand Petroleum and Minerals| date=30 May 2017}} Over 80% of New Zealand's coal reserves are contained in Southland lignite deposits. Most coal production is of bituminous and sub-bituminous coals, and most of this is exported.{{cite web| url=http://www.mbie.govt.nz/info-services/sectors-industries/energy/energy-data-modelling/statistics/coal| title=Coal| work=Energy Statistics| publisher=MBIE| date=4 October 2017}} === Oil and gas === {{main|Oil and gas industry in New Zealand}} Oil and gas is produced from 21 petroleum licenses / permits, all in the Taranaki basin.{{cite web |url=http://www.crownminerals.govt.nz/cms/petroleum/overview |title=Petroleum Overview |publisher=Crown Minerals, Ministry of Economic Development|date=26 June 2008}} The most important fields are [[Kapuni]], [[Maui gas field|Maui]], [[Pohokura field|Pohokura]] and [[Kupe field|Kupe]]. Exploration for oil and gas reserves includes the [[Great South Basin]] and offshore areas near Canterbury and Gisborne. Reticulated natural gas is available in most major North Island towns and cities. === Renewable energy === {{main|Renewable energy in New Zealand}} Approximately 40% of primary energy is from renewable energy sources. Approximately 80% of electricity comes from renewable energy, primarily [[hydroelectric power in New Zealand|hydropower]] and [[geothermal power in New Zealand|geothermal power]]. Studies have shown that it is technically feasible to provide 100% of the electricity demand by renewable power without risking with shortages in energy supply.Mason et al., ''A 100% renewable electricity generation system for New Zealand utilising hydro, wind, geothermal and biomass resources.'' In: ''[[Energy Policy (journal)|Energy Policy]]'' 38, (2010), 3973–3984, {{DOI|10.1016/j.enpol.2010.03.022}}.Mason et al, ''Security of supply, energy spillage control and peaking options within a 100% renewable electricity system for New Zealand.'' In: ''[[Energy Policy (journal)|Energy Policy]]'' 60, (2013),324–333, {{DOI|10.1016/j.enpol.2013.05.032}}. == Energy consumption == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:right;" |+ New Zealand consumed energy 2017 ([[Petajoule|PJ]]) |- ! Fuel !! Total !! Primary !! Industrial !! Commercial !! Transport !!
